From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

English

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From incline +‎ -er.

Noun

[edit]

incliner (plural incliners)

  1. Someone or something that inclines, especially an inclined dial.

References

[edit]
  • “incliner”, in Webster’s Revised Unabridged Dictionary, Springfield, Mass.: G. & C. Merriam, 1913, →OCLC.

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Learned borrowing from Latin inclīnāre (“incline, tilt”). Supplanted the inherited Old French encliner.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ɛ̃.kli.ne/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (France (Lyon)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)

Verb

[edit]

incliner

  1. to incline
  2. (reflexive) to lose
  3. (reflexive) to set, to go down

1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Derived terms

[edit]

  • plan incliné

Related terms

[edit]

Further reading

[edit]

Latin

[edit]

Verb

[edit]

inclīner

  1. first-person singular present passive subjunctive of inclīnō
